In a graphical user interface such as Windows, a pattern or picture in the screen background that can be chosen by the user.
To attach a label to.

On IBM and PC-compatible computers, a key whose function changes depending on the application program. Usually it erases the character under the cursor, although in some applications it can erase selected text or graphics.
To wait for incoming traffic, calls or connection requests on a port.
To be unresponsive.
A tool for accessing right-click menus and targeting small pieces of the interface using touch input.

An application of the Standard Generalized Markup Language that uses tags to mark elements, such as text and graphics, in a document to indicate how Web browsers should display these elements to the user and should respond to user actions.

An application of the Standard Generalized Markup Language that uses tags to mark elements, such as text and graphics, in a document to indicate how Web browsers should display these elements to the user and should respond to user actions.
A form of assistance in which a program that provides on-screen help shows information to the user concerning the current command or operation being attempted.
A list of domain names and email addresses that are treated as junk email and are blocked unless the sender is on the Safe Senders List or the recipient is on the Safe Recipients List.
A copy of a master, which you create by dragging the master from a stencil to a drawing.
An item in the Journal folder that acts as a shortcut to an activity that has been recorded.

The Book.xlt template that you create to change the default format of new workbooks. Excel uses the template to create a blank workbook when you start Excel or create a new workbook without specifying a template.
To activate something making it available for use.
A visual display of data in a dashboard that can be coordinated with other report views by using filters.
A value that represents the result of an invalid calculation.
A value that represents the result of an invalid calculation.
The process of writing new data to computer memory.
A visual indication that represents the current location being played within the selected media.
A color that is mixed with black. A 10-percent shade is one part of the original color and nine parts black.
The feature of partial control parents get over the accounts and devices of their children helping them supervise how their children behave online and letting them restrict what their children see.
Combined earphone and microphone set that enables hands-free communication.
The slide text on the slide master. The master text determines the format of text on all slides as well as the shape of text placeholders and their placement on slides.
The naming convention for disk drives or partitions on most computers, consisting of an alphabetical letter followed by a colon.
A control on a form, that repeats as needed, into which users can enter text. The control can be formatted as a bulleted, numbered, or plain list.
The appearance of the Start menu and the taskbar after the glass visual style has been applied to customize the color, intensity, and opacity of window borders.
An icon that designates a change made by a reviewer to a presentation.
A second calendar format selected by the user from within Outlook and visible in dual calendar view.
A sequence of words or other text used to gain access to a network, program, or data. A passphrase is generally longer for added security.
A task pane with options that enable the user to send a Publisher file as personalized, individually addressed email to the recipients in the specified list.
A process of copying content and/or configuration settings from one location, generally a server node, to another to ensure synchronization or fault tolerance.
A typographical unit of measure that is equal to one sixth of an inch.
A OneNote item that has been marked with a note tag.
A configuration parameter that controls the behavior of a service, application, feature, function, or a run-time environment.
A route through a structured collection of information, as in a database, a program, or files stored on disk.
To align text along the right margin.
The area in each row of a database table that stores the data value for some attribute of the object modeled by the table.
A title animation in Windows Movie Maker.
The protection of information assets through the use of technology, processes, and training.
The point at which one page ends and another begins.

The full Internet address of a page or other World Wide Web resource. The absolute URL includes a protocol, such as "http," network location, and optional path and file name — for example, http://example.microsoft.com/.
A method computers use to send and receive email messages. It allows you to access email without downloading it to your computer or device.
A method computers use to send and receive email messages. It allows you to access email without downloading it to your computer or device.

A Microsoft Exchange mailbox that allocates a specific number of connections. The resource serves as a virtual room for your online meeting. You invite the resource to an online meeting just as you would reserve a room for a meeting.
A menu choice or remote button that offers access to the user's video library.

A small, Internet Protocol (IP)-based network. It is usually used for short-range, ad-hoc communication between devices and computers. A PAN may also be used to enable connectivity to a larger Local Area Network (LAN), Wide-Area Network (WAN), or the Internet. Windows XP supports the Bluetooth PAN service so you can create Personal Area Networks using Bluetooth.

A small, Internet Protocol (IP)-based network. It is usually used for short-range, ad-hoc communication between devices and computers. A PAN may also be used to enable connectivity to a larger Local Area Network (LAN), Wide-Area Network (WAN), or the Internet. Windows XP supports the Bluetooth PAN service so you can create Personal Area Networks using Bluetooth.

Authorization to perform operations associated with a specific shared resource, such as a file, directory, or printer and that must be granted by the system administrator to individual user accounts or administrative groups.

Authorization to perform operations associated with a specific shared resource, such as a file, directory, or printer and that must be granted by the system administrator to individual user accounts or administrative groups.
An option that changes a 2-dimensional linear expression, such as 5^2, to a built-up (3-dimensional) format.
The ultimate user of a computer or computer application in its finished, marketable form.
A reference to a specific legal case, statute, or other legal document.
A person who is involved in the creation of content. For example editors, technical reviewers and subject matter experts are contributors.
The amount of space from the bottom of one line of text to the bottom of the next line.
The amount of space from the bottom of one line of text to the bottom of the next line.
A value assigned to an item of media content that indicates its suitability for a particular audience.
A chart consisting of horizontal or vertical bars, the widths or heights of which represent the values of numerical data.
A dialog box that allows users to add/remove/organize the list of bibliographic information for the document
A keyboard character that can be used to represent one or many characters when conducting a query.
The combination of a number of products for sale as one unit.
The text of a WordArt object.
A network within an organization that uses Internet technologies and protocols, but is available only to certain people, such as employees of a company.
A person whose information, such as ID or email address, has been added by the user to their contact list or to an address book.
A character, such as diacritic, that has no meaning by itself, but overlaps a base character to modify it.
A character, such as diacritic, that has no meaning by itself, but overlaps a base character to modify it.
A group that controls which system locale, user locales, input locales, and user interface (UI) languages can be selected.
The horizontal arrangement of cells in a table or spreadsheet.
A summary of one's academic and work history, usually submitted with a job application.
A summary of one's academic and work history, usually submitted with a job application.
Software that fulfills the deliberately harmful intent of an attacker when run.
Software that fulfills the deliberately harmful intent of an attacker when run.
A standard Windows control that can be used to provide interactive column titles for a list.
A menu option on the Property Panel that enables the user to specify document properties.
To end an application's relationship with an open file so that the application will no longer be able to access the file without opening it again.
A symbol that is displayed beside a paragraph in outline view. You can use the symbol to display or hide subordinate levels of text and to reorganize text quickly.
A complete Web site stored in a named subdirectory of the top-level Web site.
A proxy server installed by a trojan on a machine providing what appears to be an uninterrupted Internet connection while allowing unauthorized access to an affected machine.
A symbol selected to designate a specific currency.
One or more fields that uniquely identify each record in a table.
The way text is displayed in a document, how it behaves and breaks according to settings.
Words or phrases that convey hatred or contempt or is intended to intimidate or cause harm to a group of people based on race, religion, ethnic origin, sexual orientation or disability.
An action query that adds the records in a query's result set to the end of an existing table.
On a disk or other direct-access storage device, a continuous block of storage space reserved by the operating system for a particular file or program.
The writing or drawing strokes that you make with your stylus or fingers.
The writing or drawing strokes that you make with your stylus or fingers.
To compress into an archive.
A mark inserted in a document to show where a comment has been added.
The field that contains a contact's mobile phone number.

A scalable, security-enhanced, standards-based solution that centralizes control and management of electronic forms by allowing customers to use a common Web browser to interact with information. It will help streamline organizations forms-driven business processes with existing systems.

A scalable, security-enhanced, standards-based solution that centralizes control and management of electronic forms by allowing customers to use a common Web browser to interact with information. It will help streamline organizations forms-driven business processes with existing systems.
A standard of video compression and file format developed by the Moving Pictures Experts Group for description and search of multimedia content data.
A standard of video compression and file format developed by the Moving Pictures Experts Group for description and search of multimedia content data.
A standard of video compression and file format developed by the Moving Pictures Experts Group for description and search of multimedia content data.
The ? character, used as a punctuation mark or wildcard character.
A string that identifies a user so that the user can receive Internet email and typically consists of an account name, followed by the @ (at) symbol, a host name, and a domain name.
A string that identifies a user so that the user can receive Internet email and typically consists of an account name, followed by the @ (at) symbol, a host name, and a domain name.
A set of conditions that hold back elements or modify the appearance of an existing list or data set in order to view a specific subset of the data.
A set of conditions that hold back elements or modify the appearance of an existing list or data set in order to view a specific subset of the data.
An area in the taskbar that shows icons for network connectivity, volume control, clock, and on laptops and Tablet computers, the battery.
To send a received content either modified or in its entirety, to a new recipient.
A client program or control that receives digital media content streamed from a server or played from local files. Windows Media Player is an example of a player.
Another site promoted by the host site.
The portion of an on-screen file that has been marked as subject to user action.
The Microsoft web browser.
The surface of a button where text or an image (typically indicating the button's function) may be displayed.
A service that notifies a user that a call is coming in while the user is in a call.
The particular range of colors that a device or color model is able to produce.
A file or set of files that defines the data structure, appearance, and behavior of a form.
The Windows-based directory service that stores information about objects on a network and makes this information available to users and network administrators.
The Windows-based directory service that stores information about objects on a network and makes this information available to users and network administrators.
A filter effect in Windows Movie Maker.

A process by which software components and layers are linked together. When a network component is installed, the binding relationships and dependencies for the components are established. Binding allows components to communicate with each other.
A unique identifier of an object or person.
A unique identifier of an object or person.
A trojan that accesses remote Web sites in order to download and install malicious or potentially unwanted software to the computer that the Trojan has infected.
An authentication credential similar to a password, consisting of numbers.
A computer that provides shared resources, such as files or printers, to network users.
A number that identifies each telephone service area in a country/region and is used as a dialing prefix.
To configure a device or application so that it performs better. For example, to fine-tune a program so that it runs more quickly or takes up less space.
A named set of deliverables (software components) produced, usually by compiling, from a discrete set of source versions.
A software control that incorporates ActiveX technology.
A chart that uses horizontal bars to illustrate comparisons among individual data items.
A chart that uses horizontal bars to illustrate comparisons among individual data items.
A picture made from a series of small dots, much like a piece of graph paper with certain squares filled in to form shapes and lines.
Pertaining to a type of access to data in a database that is shared over a network. When you open a database in exclusive mode, you prevent others from opening the database.
A supplemental program that can extend the capabilities of an application program.
To tap twice quickly on a screen or touchpad.
To adjust the perspective of an image or document in order to view a larger area on the screen at one time, as if viewed from farther away.
The menu choice that allows a user to customize application behavior.
The sheet that you're working on in a workbook. The name on the tab of the active sheet is bold.
A customizable toolbar that provides one-click access to commands.
A control on a menu, toolbar, dialog box, or data access page that displays a list of options when you click the small arrow next to the list box.

A card, plug, or other device that connects pieces of hardware with the computer so that information can be moved from place to place. For example, standardized interfaces such as RS-232-C standard and SCSI enable communications between computers and printers or disks.

A card, plug, or other device that connects pieces of hardware with the computer so that information can be moved from place to place. For example, standardized interfaces such as RS-232-C standard and SCSI enable communications between computers and printers or disks.
A setting in which existing characters are replaced with newly typed characters.
A capability of many programs and operating systems to display advice or instructions for using their features when so requested by the user, as by a screen button or menu item or a function key.

In facsimile and other optical technologies, to move a light-sensitive device across an image-bearing surface such as a page of text, converting the light and dark areas on the surface to binary digits that can be interpreted by a computer.
A small graphical symbol the user can insert into instant messages.
An individual song or other discrete piece of audio content.

A button that represents an item or program that is open and running on your computer. For example, if you open Microsoft Word, and then minimize it, it will be displayed as a taskbar button, which you can then click when you want to maximize it.

To detect, locate, and correct logical or syntactical errors in a program or malfunctions in hardware. In hardware contexts, the term troubleshoot is the term more often used, especially when the problem is a major one.

A testing process that supplies structured but invalid input to software application programming interfaces (APIs) and network interfaces to maximize the likelihood of detecting errors that might lead to software vulnerabilities.
A program that installs other potentially unwanted software, such as adware or spyware. The license agreement of the bundling program may require these other components in order to function.
A microphone feature that allows your input to be amplified so that it is made louder for use by the system.
An executable program file that contains one or more compressed text or data files. When a user runs the program, it uncompresses the compressed files and stores them on the user's hard drive.

Of or relating to communications systems in which the medium of transmission (such as a wire or fiber-optic cable) carries multiple messages at a time, each message modulated on its own carrier frequency by a modem.
The Windows technology that collects data when the system crashes or stops responding and sends it to Microsoft.
One of the presets for 3D rotation effects. When selected, specifies that the object will be rotated isometrically.
To mark text, cells, and similar items that will be subject to a user action, such as copying text.
The feature that provides a home for the Office Scrapbook, Compatibility Report, Project Palette and Reference Pane and is shown as a floating palette.
The price at which a buyer has offered to purchase an item.
The menu item that allows the play back all of the items in a playlist once, in random order. Playback ends when all of the items in the list have been played one time.
A network of computers, printers, and other devices located within a relatively limited area (for example, a building). A LAN enables any connected device to interact with any other on the network.
A network of computers, printers, and other devices located within a relatively limited area (for example, a building). A LAN enables any connected device to interact with any other on the network.
A network of computers, printers, and other devices located within a relatively limited area (for example, a building). A LAN enables any connected device to interact with any other on the network.

The process of seeking a particular file or specific data. A search is carried out by a program through comparison or calculation to determine whether a match to some pattern exists or whether some other criteria have been met.

To perform an action that entails pressing a finger or the tip of a pen to the screen, holding it down until a mouse icon or menu appears, and then lifting the finger or pen. Pressing and holding is equivalent to right-clicking with a mouse.
Part of the Office Center feature that allows users to set various security and privacy options, and to see currently enforced security and privacy rules.
To move the pointer over a UI element for a specified duration with the intent of interacting with that element.
Completed or passed. The measured duration of an event.
A handheld portable telephone that operates through a radio network.
To move an object one pixel at a time.
A repository that is separate from the user’s mailbox and that allows items to be archived on the server.

A Control Panel icon in Windows Vista that allows parents and guardians to customize key aspects of their children’s online and computing experience through the use of features such as game ratings and activity reports.
The area of the window that displays the criteria used to limit the records included in the result set of your query.
The } character.
Additional information required by some macro actions - for example, the object affected by the action or special conditions under which the action is carried out.
Data in its unencrypted or decrypted form.
The basic building block of a macro; a self-contained instruction that can be combined with other actions to automate tasks. This is sometimes called a command in other macro languages.
A room, computer, or any equipment needed at a meeting.
The areas surrounding many 3-D chart types that give dimension and boundaries to the chart. Two walls and one floor are displayed within the plot area.

A message that has been sent across one or more messaging systems. It may have been sent only to you or to many other recipients. Incoming messages are placed in a receive folder designated to hold messages of a particular class. You can set up a different receive folder for each message class that you handle or use one folder for all of the classes.

The person responsible for setting up and managing local computers, stand-alone servers, member servers, or domain controllers. An administrator performs such duties as assigning user accounts and passwords, establishing security access levels, watching for unauthorized access, allocating storage space, and helping users with networking problems.

The person responsible for setting up and managing local computers, stand-alone servers, member servers, or domain controllers. An administrator performs such duties as assigning user accounts and passwords, establishing security access levels, watching for unauthorized access, allocating storage space, and helping users with networking problems.
To prepare a disk, computer, device, or system for use.
The ’ character (publishing character).
The computational and control unit of a computer. The CPU is the device that interprets and executes instructions.
The computational and control unit of a computer. The CPU is the device that interprets and executes instructions.
A commercial organization.
An alphanumeric code assigned to all addresses in order to facilitate mail delivery.
A combination of a digital certificate and a public and private encryption key set.
A piece of text entered by a user that is displayed to contacts.
The list or table that's used to create a PivotTable or PivotChart report. Source data can be taken from an Excel list or range, an external database or cube, or another PivotTable report.
To add a digital signature to a macro or file.
A peripheral device whose purpose is to allow the user to provide input to a computer system. Examples of input devices are keyboards, mice, joysticks, and styluses.
One character (or more) that is slightly higher than other text on a line, such as a footnote reference mark.
A Windows technology that protects OS resources (files, folders registry keys) and prevents applications and administrators from making changes to a computer's resources in an arbitrary way.

A chart that provides interactive analysis of data, like a PivotTable report. You can change views of data, see different levels of detail, or reorganize the chart layout by dragging fields and by showing or hiding items in fields.
A memory measurement unit that is equal to 1 million bytes.
A memory measurement unit that is equal to 1 million bytes.
In computing, a characteristic of data that is represented as binary digits (zeros and ones).
To make a transmission appear to come from a user other than the user who performed the action.
A diagramming capability that shows charts in three dimensions.
To adjust horizontal spacing so that text is aligned evenly along both the left and right margins. Justifying text creates a smooth edge on both sides.
A change made to content, such as a file, document, or post.
A file that saves display information about open workbooks, so that you can later resume work with the same window sizes, print areas, screen magnification, and display settings.
To set a variable to an initial value.
Amusment, pleasure, or diversion.
A calendar item that includes reserved resources and/or invited attendees.
The process of adjusting display resolution based on monitor resolution.
A frequently updated online journal or column.
A legal agreement between a software or hardware manufacturer and the end user, with regard to the terms of use and transfer of the software.
Any measurable, tangible, verifiable outcome, result, or item that must be produced to complete a project or part of a project.

The extension of a private network that encompasses encapsulated, encrypted, and authenticated links across shared or public networks. VPN connections typically provide remote access and router-to-router connections to private networks over the Internet.

The extension of a private network that encompasses encapsulated, encrypted, and authenticated links across shared or public networks. VPN connections typically provide remote access and router-to-router connections to private networks over the Internet.
A link between two or more communications devices.
The technology in Windows that lets customers create a system image for backing up their hard drive and related system settings, programs, and files.
A device used to connect wireless computers and other wireless devices to a wired network.
To end a user session for an Internet account. For example, you sign out of a Microsoft account, an Internet service provider account, or Skype.
The layer of the asynchronous transfer mode (ATM) protocol stack that parses data into the payload portion of the ATM cell for transport across an ATM network.
The layer of the asynchronous transfer mode (ATM) protocol stack that parses data into the payload portion of the ATM cell for transport across an ATM network.

Any shape that you draw by using the Curve, Freeform, and Scribble tools. Freeform shapes can include straight lines and freehand curves. They can be drawn opened or closed and can be edited by using the drawing tools.
Hearing impairment that results in complete loss of hearing.
A person who sends spam.
A symmetric-key encryption cipher that applies the Data Encryption Standard (DES) cipher algorithm three times to each data block.
A symmetric-key encryption cipher that applies the Data Encryption Standard (DES) cipher algorithm three times to each data block.
A symmetric-key encryption cipher that applies the Data Encryption Standard (DES) cipher algorithm three times to each data block.
A framework that includes rows and columns for organizing and arranging content on a form, including controls, control labels, sections of a form, logos, and other types of graphics.

Paragraph formatting you can use to assign a hierarchical level (Level 1 through Level 9) to paragraphs in your document. For example, after you assign outline levels, you can work with the document in outline view or in the Document Map.
A small pop-up window that describes the object being pointed to, such as a control, icon, or links. It contains more information than a standard tooltip.
A general class of software used to detect spyware and sometimes remove it.
A symbol used to represent the Control key on the keyboard. For example, ^Z means "hold the Control key down and press the Z key."
To accept changes to data in a record.
The last line of a paragraph printed by itself at the top of a page.
The data type that holds a maximum of 8,000 characters.
An action statement in any computer language, most often in machine or assembly language. Most programs consist of two types of statements: declarations and instructions.
A query (SQL statement) that removes rows matching the criteria you specify from one or more tables.
Video images and sound stored in a digital format.
Video images and sound stored in a digital format.
A graphical user interface control that is equipped with a small bar which slides along a visible line and is used to set a value along a range with a minimum and maximum.
To reduce a window to a button on the taskbar by clicking the Minimize button (leftmost button on the right side of the title bar) or by pressing ALT+SPACEBAR and then pressing N.

A window that displays the SQL statement for the current query or that is used to create an SQL-specific query (union, pass-through, or data definition). When you create a query in Design view, Access constructs the SQL equivalent in SQL view.
A query that asks a question about the data stored in your tables and returns a result set in the form of a datasheet, without changing the data.
A single location in Windows where you can adjust mobile PC settings.
A file that contains encoded information that is interpreted according to the application that created it. In general, a binary file can be edited only by the application in which it was created.
An interactive technology in Microsoft Excel or Access that can show dynamic views of the same data from a list or a database.

A Microsoft Office Web Component that allows you to create a structure similar to an Excel PivotTable report. Users can view the PivotTable list in a Web browser and change its layout in a manner similar to an Excel PivotTable report.
The button on your pointing device that you use to display shortcut menus or other program-specific features.
Confidence in the reliability of an entity or service and the information that it provides.
A user interface control that facilitates modification of an object's appearance, position, or behavior.
A change to an account to correct or update the balance.
The date by which some task or action should be completed.
An artificial intelligence program that performs a task on a network as an agent for a user or another program.

A graphic element that appears similar to a physical button or keyboard key in the UI. A button is "pressed" by clicking on it with a mouse, by hitting ENTER or RETURN on the keyboard (if the button has the focus) or tapping by a finger.
An automated tool that helps find and fix specific problems on your computer.
The key on the keyboard that is labeled with a left arrow.

A set of industry-standard framing and authentication protocols that are included with Windows to ensure interoperability with other remote access software. PPP negotiates configuration parameters for multiple layers of the Open Systems Interconnection (OSI) model. The Internet standard for serial communications, PPP defines how data packets are exchanged with other Internet-based systems using a modem connection. PPP is documented in RFC 1661.

A set of industry-standard framing and authentication protocols that are included with Windows to ensure interoperability with other remote access software. PPP negotiates configuration parameters for multiple layers of the Open Systems Interconnection (OSI) model. The Internet standard for serial communications, PPP defines how data packets are exchanged with other Internet-based systems using a modem connection. PPP is documented in RFC 1661.

An email security feature used to request confirmation that a message was received unaltered and information about who opened the message and when it was opened. This verification information is returned as a message to your Inbox.
The Microsoft technology that facilitates the installation of updates to Windows operating systems by scanning and installing to client systems in a way that permits end user control over the process
The app that calculates (standard and scientific) and converts.
The app that calculates (standard and scientific) and converts.
The app that calculates (standard and scientific) and converts.
A scheme for uniquely identifying resources that may be available on the Internet by name, without regard to where they are located.
A scheme for uniquely identifying resources that may be available on the Internet by name, without regard to where they are located.

An XML file with an .xsf extension that contains information about all other files and components used within a form, including user interface customizations, XML Schemas, views, business logic, events, and deployment settings.
A detail about a file that helps identify it, such as a descriptive title, the author name, the subject, or a keyword that identifies topics or other important information in the file.
A Web hosting and Internet service provider who manages the Web server hardware and software required to make a Web site available on the Internet.
Multimedia content in software, on CD-ROM, or on a Web site that purports to educate the user as well as entertain.
The window in which a user is currently working or directing input. An active window is typically at the top of the Z order and is distinguished by the color of its title bar.
A field data type that can contain up to 255 characters or the number of characters specified by the Fieldsize property, whichever is less.
A unit of measure referring to the height of a printed character. A point equals 1/72 of an inch, or approximately 1/28 of a centimeter.

The part of the Microsoft Office user interface above the main work area that presents commands and options to the user. The Ribbon replaced menus and toolbars starting in the 2007 Microsoft Office system.
An indent where the text is displaced into the left margin if text direction is set to left-to-right, or toward the right margin if text direction is set to right-to-left.
A field data type that can contain up to 65,535 characters.
A window in an email program where you can preview an item without opening it.
An orientation where the long dimension of a rectangular area (for example, screen, photo, or paper) is horizontal.
A number assigned to a specific inventory item to identify it and differentiate it from similar items with the same item number.
A logical network connection between two entities such as a user or computer, that has a defined lifetime and associated state, and that might involve multiple physical connections.
To pick a command or an option from within a graphical user interface, as by clicking a button in a dialog box or pulling down a menu and then releasing the mouse button on one of its options.
A unit of measure used in typesetting and desktop publishing, equal to one-twentieth of a printer's point, or 1/1440th of an inch.
A Web page editor command that inserts a horizontal line onto a Web page.
A tool that enables a user to sample the color of any pixel on a screen and apply that color to an object.
To assign or reserve a portion of an element, such as a resource or a session, for a particular use or purpose.

A page that contains the design and layout elements that you want to repeat on multiple pages in a publication. Using master pages for these common elements gives your publication a more consistent appearance.
A box with dotted borders in a slide layout that holds title and body text or objects such as charts, tables, and pictures.
A unit of information transmitted from one computer or device to another on a network.
To continue to press a keyboard key or mouse button.
A detailed summary of one's academic and work history and experience, including information about research, publications, and/or academic or personal interests and achievements.
A detailed summary of one's academic and work history and experience, including information about research, publications, and/or academic or personal interests and achievements.
A lightweight and task-specific add-in program that integrates with applications to expose data at a glance.
The amount of storage space available for storing and processing on a disc.

A markup language for describing and exchanging structured data in a format that is independent of operating systems and applications. XML is a World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) specification and is a subset of Standard Generalized Markup Language (SGML).
The $ character.

A Windows security feature that locks a user account if a number of failed logon attempts occur within a specified amount of time, based on security policy lockout settings. Locked accounts cannot log on.
A line or row of characters used to lead the eye from a data label to a data point, or from a callout to the appropriate part of an illustration.
A line or row of characters used to lead the eye from a data label to a data point, or from a callout to the appropriate part of an illustration.
A field in a table that draws data from another table.
In a cascading style sheet style definition (or style rule), the HTML element linked to a particular set of style properties and values.
A feature that helps improve the recognition of a user's touch flicks by a process in which the user's touch flicks are analyzed.

An address that uniquely identifies a location on the Internet. A URL is usually preceded by http://, as in http://www.microsoft.com. A URL can contain more detail, such as the name of a page of hypertext, often with the file name extension .html or .htm.

An address that uniquely identifies a location on the Internet. A URL is usually preceded by http://, as in http://www.microsoft.com. A URL can contain more detail, such as the name of a page of hypertext, often with the file name extension .html or .htm.
An object that supports the OLE protocol for object linking and embedding.
In statistical or scientific data, a bar that shows the potential error or degree of uncertainty relative to each data marker in a series.
The points where playback of a file or clip begins and ends. There are two trim points: start trim point and end trim point.
The > character.
An agreement in which a customer prepays for periodic or regular services.
An agreement in which a customer prepays for periodic or regular services.

Characterized by conversational exchange of input and output, as when a user enters a question or command and the system immediately responds. The interactivity of microcomputers is one of the features that makes them approachable and easy to use.

A noticeable element of the new Windows Aero experience is the professional-looking, transparent glass design, which creates an open, lightweight environment but more importantly enables users to focus on their content rather than the interface.

Customers may either buy full packaged product (FPP) or upgrade quickly and conveniently electronically.

A formal or legally binding agreement between two or more parties.

Paragraph formatting in which the second and subsequent lines of a paragraph are indented more than the first line.

A group of preset power-management options. For example, you can set elapsed times for putting your computer on standby and for turning off your monitor and hard disk. You save these settings as a named power scheme.

A margin setting that adds extra space to the side or top margin of a document you plan to bind. A gutter margin ensures that text isn't obscured by the binding.

Content has been hashed and verified as valid against the signature. The certificate used to verify the signature is “valid” in the sense that it has a relationship to a trusted certificate authority (and isn’t expired, etc.)
A hard plastic disc on a mouse that is perpendicular to the mouse surface. It is normally located between the left and right mouse buttons and is used for scrolling.
A feature that allows the user to select from a gallery of pre-defined formatting styles and apply them quickly to tables, text, charts, drawing objects and SmartArt graphics.

A secure email feature that lets you add sensitivity labels, such as Internal Use Only, to the message header. Security labels in your organization are controlled by security policies set up by your email administrator.
A rectangle with sizing handles that surrounds a selected object or objects.
To position objects or text relative to some point, such as the page margin.
Pertaining to a file format that allows for VBA code. Examples of file extensions for macro-enabled formats are .docm, .pptm, .xlsm.
A feature in Office Server that provides a workflow for document review.
A dialog box that displays one complete record at a time. You can use data forms to add, change, locate, and delete records.
In Windows Media Player, a database that contains information about digital media files on a computer, a network drive, or the Internet.
One or more rows of cells commonly used to display numbers and other items for quick reference and analysis.

The cell in which each input value from a data table is substituted. Any cell on a worksheet can be the input cell. Although the input cell does not need to be part of the data table, the formulas in data tables must refer to the input cell.
The adjustment of the spacing between two characters to create the appearance of even spacing, fit text to a given space, and adjust line breaks.
One character (or more) printed slightly below the baseline of surrounding text.

The core component of the Excel Server that includes the full Excel calculation functionality. It loads and saves Excel workbooks, queries and refreshes external data, calculates workbooks, and provides the calculated results to the caller.
In the context of processes or tasks that are part of an operating system or program, operating without interaction with the user while the user is working on another task.
To advance audio or video playback at a speed that is faster than normal.

A type of attack that tries to trick users into revealing personal information, such as credit card numbers, bank accounts, or passwords, often using links to fake websites included in emails and chat messages.

An item provided and signed by the DCE security server that is both a proof of identity and a list of group memberships.
The feature of an integrated development environment (IDE) that provides logical code elements that the user can select from a drop-down menu while coding.
A column chart subtype that compares values across categories. The categories are organized horizontally, and values vertically, to emphasize variation over time.
A column chart subtype that compares the percentage that each value contributes to a total across categories.
A column chart subtype that compares data points along two axes.
A variation on a column chart that uses cylinder shapes instead of rectangular columns.
A variation on a column chart that uses cone shapes instead of rectangular columns.
A variation on a column chart that uses pyramid shapes instead of rectangular columns.
A stacked column chart that creates the effect of floating columns by making the first data series invisible. The result is a chart that depicts minimum and maximum values.

A variation on a bar chart that uses pyramid shapes instead of horizontal rectangles.
A variation on a bar chart that uses cylinder shapes instead of horizontal rectangles.

A bar chart subtype that compares values across categories.
A pie chart with user-defined values extracted and combined into a second pie.
A pie chart with user-defined values extracted and combined into a stacked bar.
A pie chart that displays the contribution of each value to a total while emphasizing individual values, by showing each slice of the pie as "pulled out," or separate, from the whole.
A chart that plots numerical data along two value axes (x,y).
A chart that plots numerical data along two value axes (x,y).
An apartment that consists of exactly one thread.
An apartment that consists of exactly one thread.
A chart that shows a three dimensional surface that connects a set of data points. As in a topographic map, colors and patterns indicate areas that are in the same range of values.
Pertaining to a resource in a failover cluster or server cluster that is in the process of being brought online or offline.
A surface chart subtype that provides a view of the surface chart from above, with colors representing specific ranges of values.
A contour chart displayed without color.
A chart that displays data in rings, where each ring represents a data series.

A trendline that smoothes out fluctuations in data to show a pattern or trend more clearly.

A directory name, used in an address, that corresponds to a physical directory on the server.

A numeric or other designation appended to a product name to identify a particular release.​
An effect applied to a graphical object that typically reduces the difference between the outline of the object and the graphical area next to it.
Software that provides encryption for sensitive data, such as passwords, in applications.
The round button in the lower left-hand corner of the Windows screen that allows the user to click and display the Start menu.

An attack by a malicious user or malicious software on a computer or operating system to find a secret password or a symmetric encryption key by guessing passwords or keys until the correct password or key is discovered.

An attack by a malicious user or malicious software on a computer or operating system to find a secret password or a symmetric encryption key by guessing passwords or keys until the correct password or key is discovered.
A Microsoft site that provides a comprehensive listing of updates that can be distributed over a corporate network.

A feature of Remote Desktop Services that enables the user to access a program remotely through Remote Desktop Services but have it appear as if it is running on the user's local computer. Users can run RemoteApp programs side by side with their local programs.

The Microsoft implementation of an integrity level. In particular, a protection level, refers to an integrity label that contains only level information, without the additional information traditionally contained within integrity level.
The date when a project or task is scheduled to begin.

A unique view for displaying appointments, tasks, and other information in the form of a Web page. You can customize the Outlook Today page for your organization, or for individuals or groups within your organization, to display the information most relevant to them.
A method of authentication by which the client in a client-server communication proves its identity to the server.
To eliminate an entity by removing it from a list, database, or other item, or by uninstalling it.
To set an entity, such as a feature, configuration, or object, back to its defaults.

The original project, resource, and assignment cost as shown in the baseline plan. The baseline cost is a snapshot of the cost at the time when the baseline plan was saved.
To briefly press a UI element with your fingertip or stylus to perform an activity (such as choosing an action from a menu or opening an item). A "tap" is normally around 0.1 second in duration.
A number from 0 to 1 that reveals how closely the estimated values for the trendline correspond to your actual data. A trendline is most reliable when its R-squared value is at or near 1.
A number from 0 to 1 that reveals how closely the estimated values for the trendline correspond to your actual data. A trendline is most reliable when its R-squared value is at or near 1.

A format, such as cell shading or font color, that Excel automatically applies to cells if a specified condition is true.
A view of an individual contact that contains all the information stored in the contact.

A set of buttons used to move through contact items displayed in Address Cards or Detailed Address Cards view. The Contact index moves the focus to the first contact whose name begins with the selected character.
The shape of how scheduled work for an assignment is distributed across time. Use a contour to control how Project schedules the work of a resource.
A programming interface to access and manipulate database objects.
In the Charts And Graphs template, a control handle on the Line Graph shape that you can drag to change the values in the graph.
A character that is used to separate the day, month, and year when date values are formatted. The characters are determined by system settings or by the Format function.
The font that a program uses by default to display text.
A remark or topic of discussion that is associated with a Web page or Microsoft Office file and is stored on a discussion server.
A picture that is stored within a document rather than being linked to a source file outside of the document.
An address similar to a URL that provides network access to an event, such as a live broadcast. Attendees go to this address to view the event from their computers.
A text string that unambiguously refers to a hardware or software component under a certain context and can be used to access the data in that component.
Data that is stored outside of the application that is currently in use.
A range of data that is brought into a worksheet but that originates outside of Excel, such as in a database or text file.

A pane located on top of the Navigation Pane that has copies of your Inbox, Sent Items, and so on. You can add, remove, and arrange folders in this pane. Collapse or expand the pane by clicking the arrow in the Favorite Folders header.

A button that identifies a field in a PivotTable or PivotChart report. You can drag the field buttons to change the layout of the report, or click the arrows next to the buttons to change the level of detail displayed in the report.

An Internet Web page or intranet page that is associated with an Outlook folder. If a page has been associated with the folder and the option is set, the Web page appears in the Outlook window whenever you select the folder.
A location on a computer's hard drive to store a local copy of a form to improve performance when opening a form subsequent times.

A method to find a specific value for a cell by adjusting the value of one other cell. When goal seeking, Excel varies the value in a cell that you specify until a formula that's dependent on that cell returns the result you want.
A rank or category assigned to a material resource that denotes functional use but not level of quality. A low-grade resource is not necessarily a low-quality resource.
A phone number format for dialing any call from any location or with a calling card.

The special characters used to extend the joiner between two Arabic characters. Used to improve the appearance of justified text by visually lengthening words rather than increasing the spacing between words. Can also function like a hyphen.
Resolving resource conflicts or overallocations by delaying or splitting certain tasks. When Project levels a resource, its selected assignments are distributed and rescheduled.
A type of cascading style sheet that exists in a separate file and is referenced throughout one or more Web pages.
A character, usually a comma or semicolon, that separates elements in a list.
A calendar that is based on cycles of the moon phase.
A range in an XML list that has been linked to an element in an XML map.
A shape on a stencil that you use repeatedly to create drawings. When you drag a shape from a stencil onto the drawing page, the shape becomes an instance of that master.
A tone in a picture that is in the middle of the tonal range, between the lightest and darkest tones
A character that does not have strong right-to-left or left-to-right language attributes.

A file you create on your hard disk or a network share to store OLAP source data for a PivotTable or PivotChart report. Offline cube files allow you to keep working when you are not connected to the OLAP server.

Principles that guide developers as they assign responsibilities to software classes and design system behavior. They are most useful when creating collaboration diagrams where messages imply responsibility.
A field that you use to enter or display how much of a task has been completed. This value is expressed as the percentage of the task duration that has been completed.
A schedule of task start and finish dates and resource and cost data.
A list of projects within an organization that may share common management of scope, budget, or resources.
Placing elements, such as text and graphics, on a page to let the page author control the exact location and layer order of a page element.
A bookmark that Microsoft Word automatically sets in each document.
The degree of excellence, or the desired standards, in a product, process, or project.
A default color category that is assigned to an item when you click the Categories column for the item in your Inbox or other table view. You set this color category from the Categorize menu.
To move a task to a lower outline level [to the right] in the Task Name field. When you indent a task, it becomes a subtask of the nearest preceding task at a higher outline level.
A task that occurs repeatedly during the course of a project. For example, you might define the weekly status meeting as a recurring task.

An Excel template (.xlt file) that includes one or more queries or PivotTable reports that are based on external data. When you save a report template, Excel saves the query definition but doesn't store the queried data in the template.
A certificate that has been cancelled by a certificate authority (CA) and is no longer valid.
A representation of the communication path between actors.

A default flag that is assigned to an item when you click the Flag Status column in your Inbox or other table view. You set the default time, date, or other criteria for the flag from the Follow Up menu.
An actor's interface component through which actors communicate with other actors.
Any one-dimensional (1-D) shape that can be glued between two shapes in a drawing to connect the shapes.
The numbered gray area to the left of each row.
An accessibility aid for people who are blind or have learning disabilities, such as dyslexia. These aids make on-screen information available as synthesized speech or a refreshable Braille display.
A field that is displayed in the series area of a chart and that contains series items. A series is a group of related data points.
A cell that has been linked to a non-repeating element in an XML map.
To change the dimensions of a shape by dragging one of its handles after it has been selected with the pointer tool.
A small overlap that extends the shape of the upper of two differently colored, abutting objects. A spread extends beyond the area that it knocks out.

A Microsoft Office Web Component that provides the interactive functionality of a spreadsheet on a Web page. You can enter data, add formulas and functions, apply filters, change formatting, and recalculate.
The default text font for worksheets. The standard font determines the default font for the Normal cell style.
A date that you set [rather than the current date] for reporting the time, cost, or performance condition of a project.
An horizontal or vertical line that divides a diagram into partitions and which is used to arrange related parts of a process.
Any application or process that you want to model. Examples of systems include a computer game, a process for assembling microchips, and a library information system.
One of a set of major and minor fonts that is applied to a file. Theme fonts, theme colors, and theme effects compose a theme.
A type of pane that presents the current scanned document as one or more small images.

The time period indicator at the top of the Gantt views, the Resource Graph view, the Task Usage view, and the Resource Usage view. You can customize it to show up to three tiers that can display various time units: top, middle, and bottom.
A special row in a list or table that provides a selection of aggregate functions useful for working with numerical data.

An arrow that shows the relationship between the active cell and its related cells. Tracer arrows are blue when pointing from a cell that provides data to another cell, and red if a cell contains an error value, such as #DIV/0!.
Optional text for a trendline, including either the regression equation or the R-squared value, or both. A trendline label can be formatted and moved; it cannot be sized.

A folder or file path on your computer or a location on your intranet from which it is safe to run code. Default trusted locations include the Templates, Addins, and Startup folders, and you can specify your own trusted locations.

A list of software publisher certificates used to digitally sign code, such as macros. Because you explicitly trust the software publishers, their code is allowed to run on your computer without needing to prompt for permission.
The percentage of a work resource’s time that is assigned to a task.
In line charts with multiple data series, bars that indicate the difference between data points in the first and last series.
A chart axis that displays scaled numerical values.
A calendar in widespread use. It was introduced in 1582 A.D. as a revision to the Julian calendar.
An XML structure that consists of a start tag, an end tag, and the information between the tags. Elements can have attributes and can contain other elements.
A switch (\#) or instruction that specifies how Microsoft Word will display the numeric result of a field.
A switch (\*) or instruction that specifies the capitalization, numeral style, and character formatting that Microsoft Word uses in a field result.
Pertaining to information that shows what has actually occurred. For example, the actual start date for a task is the day that the task actually started.
The percentage of a resource's capacity that is designated for a specific assignment.
An allowed path from one state to another.
The number of levels that a task is indented from the top level of the outline. You can indent tasks up to 65,000 levels in Project.
Resource cost per hour. Project includes two types of pay rates: standard rates and overtime rates.
A group of related tasks that completes a major step in a project.
Conditions you specify to limit which records are included in the result set of a query or filter.
A diagram that shows dependencies between project tasks. Tasks are represented by boxes, or nodes, and task dependencies are represented by lines that connect the boxes.
Text that you enter by using a keyboard or that your Tablet PC converts from handwriting or speech.
Software that enables parents and guardians to customize children's web experiences in order to help protect their safety and privacy online.
Software that enables parents and guardians to customize children's web experiences in order to help protect their safety and privacy online.
Software that enables parents and guardians to customize children's web experiences in order to help protect their safety and privacy online.
The folder that by default receives new messages.
A tool that enables a user to get another user's attention by shaking the user's conversation window and playing a sound.
An animated greeting a customer can send to a contact.
To package your publication files by using the Pack and Go Wizard.
A person who is not required to attend a meeting.
An initial value used to generate pseudorandom numbers.
The ability of one element to see or refer to another. For one element to send a message to another element, the latter must be visible to the former.
The primary address that is used in mail merges.
A computer simulation of a physical object in which length, width, and depth are real attributes: a model, with x-, y-, and z-axes, that can be rotated for viewing from different angles.
An effect that applies a halo of color around the perimeter of an object.
To display an object.
A file that stores an image as graphical objects (lines, circles, polygons) rather than as pixels. Metafiles preserve an image more accurately than pixels when the image is resized.
A page that you can assign to another page to create multiple layers in a drawing.
The size of the finished page of a printed publication, after trimming.
The size of the sheet of paper on which you print the publication, before trimming.
A word or string of characters in a formula that represents a cell, range of cells, formula, or constant value.
A name for an Excel table, which is a collection of data about a particular subject that is stored in records (rows) and fields (columns).
A display mode that shows as much content as possible by hiding elements such as navigation and toolbars.

When a ribbon is divided into multiple views, any one of the views. Every tab contains functionally related commands and other controls that are organized in groups. Typically, ribbon tabs are labeled.
An effect that applies to the exterior border around each character of your text or shape.
An effect that applies to the appearance of the interior of an enclosed text character or other shape.
A file that contains the data that a program will process and store in a destination file.
The distance between the camera’s lens and the image plane.
A feature that identifies elements in your file that aren't supported or will behave differently in a different format or previous version of the product.
A person who has been invited to an event.
To answer a message.
To accept an incoming telephone call.
To execute a program.
A picture made by combining a series of photos into one large picture to provide a complete view of an area or location that cannot fit in a single shot.
A collection of communications (email, IM, text messaging, voice mail, and so on) between two or more participants.
A short alphanumeric message that is sent between mobile phones or devices using the SMS protocol.
A short alphanumeric message that is sent between mobile phones or devices using the SMS protocol.
A short alphanumeric message that is sent between mobile phones or devices using the SMS protocol.
A short alphanumeric message that is sent between mobile phones or devices using the SMS protocol.

Extra information displayed to a user while they are composing an email message. MailTips are displayed in an InfoBar, similar to the banner that appears saying "This message has not been sent." MailTips reveal anything that might be unexpected about the delivery or audience of the message, such as recipient validity or Out of Office status or whether the message might not be delivered.

A collection of shapes arranged in a tree structure that helps analyze and summarize data in a visual, easy-to-understand format. It starts out as a single shape, called a top node, that contains information imported from a worksheet, table, view, or cube.
A policy that specifies the length of time during which items such as data, documents, builds, and releases are to be retained.
A sequence of data such as numbers, number and text combinations, dates, or time periods, based on an established pattern and used to automatically fill data into worksheet cells.
To stop displaying an application’s active window on screen while leaving the application running.
The window that displays solutions, projects, and files, as well as access to the commands that pertain to them.
A drop-down button that performs a default action and can also expand to a list of other possible actions.
The information provided with a product by a manufacturer describing how to use a product.
A program that extends the capabilities of a browser.
A list of things to be done or considered.

A collection of visual elements and sounds for your computer desktop or device User Interface. A theme determines the look of the various visual elements of your User Interface, such as windows, icons, fonts, and colors, and it can include sounds.

The Internet Explorer feature that allows users to surf the Web without leaving a browsing history, cookies or other information on the PC so they can do online banking on a shared computer, for example.
The service for wireless products that allows users to send and receive brief messages consisting of text and numbers to and from mobile phones and devices.

A virtual community that provides people with opportunities to interact (via blogs, chats, newsgroups, webcasts, user groups, and forums) with Microsoft employees, experts, and peers in order to share knowledge and news about Microsoft technology.
A calendar view that displays all scheduled items.
An alert that is set by the user to be activated at a particular time.
A renamed .cab file which contains a .theme file, and optionally one or more desktop backgrounds, icons, mouse pointer files, and sound files. It does not contain executables or screen savers.
A folder that stores the user's graphics, e.g. digital pictures. Many graphic design and photo-editing programs use this location by default to open or save graphic files.
A button that replaces the File menu beginning with some 2007 Microsoft Office system programs.
A button that replaces the File menu beginning with some 2007 Microsoft Office system programs.

An option on the Views menu in File Explorer that shows the most appropriate details for the file type in a flexible layout rather than only showing the details associated with the column headers in the view.
The feature in Control Panel that provides the user with a single point of entry for tasks and notifications related to security and general PC software maintenance.

A gallery that allows users to create a quick rule to move mail to a selected folder based on the sender, recipients, or conversation of the currently selected email message without opening the full Create Rule dialog.
A group of computers on a home network that can share pictures, music, videos, documents, and printers. A homegroup is created by using the HomeGroup feature; it is protected with a password.
A password that helps prevent unauthorized access to homegroup files and printers.
An action that removes redundant messages from an email conversation to reduce information overload and improve readability.
A fork within a conversation, where more than one reply was made to a single email and caused a split in the conversation.
An instant message session with multiple parties, exchanged via IM (not through your mobile operator).
An instant message session with multiple parties, exchanged via IM (not through your mobile operator).
An instant message session with multiple parties, exchanged via IM (not through your mobile operator).
A feature that replicates formatting from a source item — such as text in Word, a cell in Excel, a control in Access, or a shape in Publisher — to one or more target items.
A collection of items, such as files and folders, assembled from various locations. The locations might be on your computer, an external hard drive, removable media, or someone else’s computer.
To mark an item so that it always appears in a specific place in the UI or in a list.
To remove an item, such as a tile, library, movie, game, or app, from a given area of the UI, to make it inaccessible in that area.
To come upon through action.
To come upon through action.
The process of using a “machine” (in most cases computer software) to translate text from one human language to another.
A pencil tool that works with texture and simulates a real life pencil in stroke.
A Windows feature that enables users to easily roll back their PC to an earlier good state while keeping their data safe.

In a call queue, a method of sending calls to agents whereby incoming calls ring all call agents one by one, from the beginning of the call agent list. If an agent dismisses or does not pick up a call, the call will ring the next agent and will try all agents until it is picked up or times out.
A process by which multiple authors edit a shared document simultaneously, or collaborate effectively even when they are not online at the same time.
A feature that provides access to gallery of frequently-used actions with the touch of a button. Users can customize the gallery to execute a combination of operations in one click.
A frame that contains text, shapes, pictures, or other content. A slide is a digital equivalent to a traditional film slide.
To mark an email conversation so that all current and future messages in the conversation are automatically moved to the Deleted Items folder.
A special control that shows pictures, names and titles of people who are attending a meeting, or who are the recipients of an email message.
A group of people who can answer calls on behalf of someone else.
A user's work day hours as specified in Microsoft Office Outlook by the day of the week and the start and end times.
An auto-reply text specified using Outlook's Automatic Replies or Out of Office Assistant.
An auto-reply text specified using Outlook's Automatic Replies or Out of Office Assistant.

descripGrp.descrip: A feature that allows the user to apply custom or default markers to items (e.g. Outlook messages or OneNote content) in order to categorize information for easy retrieval and sorting.
A feature that allows the user to apply custom or default markers to items (e.g. Outlook messages or OneNote content) in order to categorize information for easy retrieval and sorting.
The feature that allows the user to fill cells with data that follows a pattern or that is based on data in other cells.
The feature that allows the user to fill cells with data that follows a pattern or that is based on data in other cells.
A tool used to turn on language-specific options for the languages one wants to use with a product.

Any hardware or software that can detect events or environmental changes, such as your current location or the amount of light around your computer. For example, a notebook with a location sensor, such as a Global Positioning System (GPS) receiver, can determine your exact location. An ambient light sensor can detect when there is a change in lighting, and then a program can use that information to adjust the brightness of your screen.

A device that includes an antenna, a radio receiver, and a processor for use with the worldwide GPS (Global Positioning System). A GPS receiver uses position and time information from four GPS satellites to calculate precise information about its current location, its speed of travel, and the current time.
A category of sensor that can detect the current location of your computer.
An area within the Windows Control Panel that provides support for sensors such as enabling, disabling or uninstalling sensors and sensor-enabled applications, changing sensor settings, etc.
An arrangement of search results ordered by relevance using a special search algorithm.
A single set of sign-in credentials (typically, email address and password) that is used to access the services provided by an online service provider (OSP).
The process of maintaining connectivity outside of one's usual service or coverage area.

A handler that displays a lightweight, read-only preview of a file’s contents without launching the application associated with the file. For example, a preview handler displays a Shell item in the Windows Explorer preview pane.
A collaborative action, such as sharing, calendar sharing, or using a whiteboard.

A set of colors and background images that lets users change the appearance of Windows Live pages. The theme is common to all pages, except for group, event, and space pages, which may each have their own theme.
A SmartArt graphic layout type that includes layouts designed to show nonsequential information.
A SmartArt graphic layout type that includes layouts designed to show steps in a process or timeline.
A SmartArt graphic layout type that includes layouts designed to show a continual process.
A SmartArt graphic layout type that includes layouts designed to show a hierarchical structure, such as an organization chart, or a decision tree.
A SmartArt graphic layout type that includes layouts designed to illustrate connections.
A SmartArt graphic layout type that includes layouts designed to show how parts relate to a whole.
A SmartArt graphic layout type that includes layouts designed to show proportional relationships with the largest component on the top or bottom.
A recognition feature that helps increase input speed and reduce effort by providing users with word completion and next word prediction alternates as the user is writing/typing.
An extension of the conventional touch input feature to allow multiple fingers touching the computer or device screen at the same time.
A multi-touch gesture that consists of one or two fingers moving in the same direction, parallel to each other.
A multi-touch gesture that consists of one or two fingers moving in the same direction, parallel to each other.
A multi-touch gesture that consists of two fingers moving in opposite directions (-> <- or <- ->).
A multi-touch gesture that consists of two fingers moving around a center point or one finger moving around a finger that is not moving.
The worldwide collection of networks and gateways that use the TCP/IP suite of protocols to communicate with one another.
The worldwide collection of networks and gateways that use the TCP/IP suite of protocols to communicate with one another.
A collection of computing resources such as programs and virtual desktops that enable a user to accomplish a set of related tasks.

The entity that offers a remote workspace, typically the IT department of the user’s employer, a business partner or vendor, or less commonly, a commercial application service provider. The publisher may use a digital certificate to represent its identity and use it to sign the remote resource files (e.g. RDP files) and the workspace description (e.g. Web Service feed).
To shut down a core processor for power saving purpose.
A unique identifier made from four otherwise separate pieces of information. For example, a color can be specified by a black, yellow, magenta and cyan quad.
To make an object, such as a file, accessible.
A feature that replicates the animation associated with a source object to one or more target objects.
An abstract grouping of similar animation effects.
An effect that a user can apply to an image to achieve a specific artistic look.
A visual representation of an audio signal over time.
An image editing feature that allows a user to isolate the foreground portion of an image and make the background transparent.
An option that removes narrations and laser pointer gestures or timings from a presentation or from a specific slide.
A set of cryptographic algorithms specified by the US National Security Agency to provide an interoperable standard for government and industry.
The portion of InfoPath used to design forms.
To remove a user's changes from the Microsoft Office Document Cache without deleting the file on the server or removing the latest version downloaded from the server from the Office Document Cache.
A security feature that validates files before allowing them to be loaded by the application, in order to protect against file format vulnerabilities.

A feature that allows the user to superimpose a dot over a presentation and control its position with the mouse. The appearance of the dot is similar to that of a traditional laser pointer, and it is broadcast to all presentation viewers and can be recorded into video (Save to Video).
An option that initiates an email response addressed to all of the recipients on the To or Cc lines of the original message.
An option that initiates an email response addressed to all of the recipients on the To or Cc lines of the original message.
The mode of Windows Photo Viewer which consists of a top level window displaying one photograph at a time, with navigation controls.
A recordable media (such as CD-RW) to which you can only write once without reformatting.
A recordable media to which you can write several times without reformatting.
A feature that is added to the Microsoft Office Compatibility Pack to open Word, Excel, and PowerPoint binary format files and securely convert them to the Office 2007 file formats.
A feature that makes Outlook auto-complete lists available through the default Exchange mailbox.
A set of credentials that users can create, store and manage in Credential Manager.

The Microsoft app that creates sticky notes that can be shared between devices, that cloud sync, that are stored on Exchange, and that provide contextual reminders and actions that can be performed based on the content.

The Microsoft app that creates sticky notes that can be shared between devices, that cloud sync, that are stored on Exchange, and that provide contextual reminders and actions that can be performed based on the content.
An individual piece of content that resembles a physical sticky note, is displayed across multiple apps and platforms, and that is created using Sticky Notes.

A feature that enables presenters in the rich client to broadcast a slide show to remote viewers watching in a Web browser. Throughout the presentation, the remote attendees will see the current slide being shown by the presenter.
A labeled group of consecutive slides that helps the user navigate and organize presentations.
A labeled group of consecutive slides that helps the user navigate and organize presentations.
A feature that makes automatic versions of user documents during each autosave operation and allows the user to revert to previous copies of the document with ease.
A feature that alerts users to potential issues with email recipients before the message is sent.
To establish a Bluetooth link or connection between two Bluetooth–enabled devices.
To make a single file out of a set of files using a program such as compress, gzip, or PKZIP.
A feature that displays a definition or translation of a word or piece of text in a ScreenTip when the pointer is moved over the selection.
A radio network that provides coverage for cellular telephone communications.

To copy driver binaries, install services, and add registry keys for one or more drivers from a driver package onto a system, without the context of a specific device. A system can be booted from reflected drivers, however full device installation may still be required in order to enable full driver functionality.
An abstract grouping of similar transition effects.

A full-page UI view that exposes file-level functionality in Office applications. This is a companion feature to the Office Ribbon and helps users discover and use the features that fall outside of the authoring features on the Ribbon.

A full-page UI view that exposes file-level functionality in Office applications. This is a companion feature to the Office Ribbon and helps users discover and use the features that fall outside of the authoring features on the Ribbon.

A full-page UI view that exposes file-level functionality in Office applications. This is a companion feature to the Office Ribbon and helps users discover and use the features that fall outside of the authoring features on the Ribbon.
A feature that helps users of some Office applications to improve the accessibility of documents they create.
An instant message that is transmitted while the sender or recipient is offline.
The helper program that can store sign-in information for multiple Windows Live IDs.
